The following is a letter issued by the Student Council expressing its stand on discrimination among Johns Hopkins student organizations. It is the result of motions made by representatives Chuck Crowell and John Sanborn at the Council's meeting last Monday.
To the Inter-Fraternity Council:
The question concerning discrimination in fraternities
was brought before the Student Council and discussed. It was
concluded that while the Student Council is opposed to discrimination in any form or organization on or off the campus,
fraternities, as private social organizations, are independent of
the student governmental structure. Therefore the Council
has no formal coercive power over them.
Recent social trends can not be ignored, however, and
we would urge the fraternity system to be aware of its responsibilities as a representative of the University. If the
policy of national fraternities prohibits acceptance of all
students, then our local chapters should do all in their power
to reverse that policy at the earliest possible date.

Concert tickets will be on sale
on Tuesday, October 20, in the
YMCA office, for $.75 and $1.00.

The Student Council

SC Condemns Discrimination
The Student Council placed itself publicly against discrimination among Johns Hopkins organizations, whether on or off
campus, in last Monday's meeting.
The Council's action followed
discussion on a report by IFC
representative Jon Shanser concerning discrimination among
campus fraternities. As reported
by Shanser, Phi Gamma Delta is
the only Hopkins fraternity still
maintaining discrimination on
the basis of race or religion. In
this case the discrimination is
against, Negroes and Orthodox
Jews.
No Waiver
Phi Gam reported to the IFC
that it will not get a waiver from
its national and doesn't want the
University to help them get one.
The fraternity feels that University interference in this area
Would be unprecedented and is
Willing to take its chances
against its occurrence. As the

matter now stands they are willing to go into second semester
rushing without the waiver and
take their chances with the
freshmen. The IFC took no action after hearing this position.
Phi Gam currently thinks that
neither they nor their national
can do anything about the situation. They cite alumni pressure
as the reason for their stand.
Ought To Do Something
It was in relation to this, and
to the failure of the IFC to do
anything further that the council made its resolution.
Dick Benzinger said, "I think
the Student Council ought to do
something, things having gone
this far." At the same ,time, the
Council felt that its powers were
limited in this area. Hence the
motion for the public letter was
adopted.
Dorm Discrimination
A freshman representative, living in Gildersleeve, asked the
Council why Negro residents in

the freshman dorms seemed to
be paired together. He wanted to
know if this were entirely by accident.
DSRC representative Benzinger replied that in roommate
selection compatibility is important and hence there is a
policy of pairing Negroes when
possible; otherwise they are
matched with Jewish boys, under
the theory that they would be
least likely to object. Roommate
selection is in the hands of Mrs.
Van Norman.
In other business, the Council
heard arguments from a pretty
Towson State mathematics major urging Hopkins to join the
Inter Collegiate Council. The
ICC is an organization comprised
of representatives from local colleges for coordinating activities
among its members. The Council voted against membership at
its previous meeting and the
spokeswoman's figures generally
fell on deaf ears.

many that he will run far behind
local candidates in many areas
of the country.
However, experts feel that his
chances have been considerably
improved by the arrest tnis week
of a top aide in the Johnson
Administration, Walter W. Jenkins, on a disorder!y conduct
charge. Jenkins has been with
Johnson since the 1930's.

Phi Gam's Clause
The hassle over Phi Gamma Delta's discriminatory
clause (which prohibits local chapters from pledging
Negroes or Orthodox Jews) seems to have reached an
impasse. The Student Council has investigated the clause,
the Interfraternity Council has discussed it, and the
News-Letter has publicized it.
All parties acknowledge that Phi Gam could not
voluntarily dissociate itself from the clause, even if it
wished to do so. A Phi Gam chapter can obtain a dispensation from the national fraternity headquarters only if
its university's or college's administration notifies the
national that unless the dispensation is granted the
chapter will lose all campus privileges.
Confronted with these facts, the IFC has decided
that the matter should he dropped and that Phi Gam
should be left to face whatever consequences may arise
from the public knowledge of its clause.
The Student Council went a hit further when it
declared its opposition to all forms of discrimination on
campus. The Council also noted that it has no coercive
power over fraternities.
Both IFC and Student Council leaders have expressed fear of intervention by the Administration.
There are some fraternity men who are opposed to
discriminatory clauses, but who also fear that if the
Administration were to step in now and notify the Phi
Gam national that the Hopkins chapter must be given a
dispensation, it would be setting a precedent for further,
perhaps unwarranted, Administration interference.
Fear of Administration action is understandable,
hut it cannot be said that such action mould he unprecedented. In the spring of 1962 a group of Administration and faculty leaders emerged from a secret
two (lay meeting to tell students of sweeping revisions
of undergraduate life that they had adopted. Included
in the revisions was an announcement that fraternities
would henceforth rush in the spring rather than in the
fall. Like every other part of the group's report, the
fraternity section was dreamt up without consulting any
students. Such action by the Administration was blatant
interference.

Phi Gam's Clause
The hassle over Phi Gamma Delta's discriminatory
clause (which prohibits local chapters from pledging
Negroes or Orthodox Jews) seems to have reached an
impasse. The Student Council has investigated the clause,
the Interfraternity Council has discussed it, and the
News-Letter has publicized it.
All parties acknowledge that Phi Gam could not
voluntarily dissociate itself from the clause, even if it
wished to do so. A Phi Gam chapter can obtain a dispensation from the national fraternity headquarters only if
its university's or college's administration notifies the
national that unless the dispensation is granted the
chapter will lose all campus privileges.
Confronted with these facts, the IFC has decided
that the matter should he dropped and that Phi Gam
should be left to face whatever consequences may arise
from the public knowledge of its clause.
The Student Council went a hit further when it
declared its opposition to all forms of discrimination on
campus. The Council also noted that it has no coercive
power over fraternities.
Both IFC and Student Council leaders have expressed fear of intervention by the Administration.
There are some fraternity men who are opposed to
discriminatory clauses, but who also fear that if the
Administration were to step in now and notify the Phi
Gam national that the Hopkins chapter must be given a
dispensation, it would be setting a precedent for further,
perhaps unwarranted, Administration interference.
Fear of Administration action is understandable,
hut it cannot be said that such action mould he unprecedented. In the spring of 1962 a group of Administration and faculty leaders emerged from a secret
two (lay meeting to tell students of sweeping revisions
of undergraduate life that they had adopted. Included
in the revisions was an announcement that fraternities
would henceforth rush in the spring rather than in the
fall. Like every other part of the group's report, the
fraternity section was dreamt up without consulting any
students. Such action by the Administration was blatant
interference.
Why, then, worry about a precedent that has already been set? A problem has been brought out that
students cannot solve themselves. Their only recourse
is to the Administration.
The Administration might be reluctant to act,
claiming that a fraternity's choice of members is its
own business. The Phi Gam national itself follows this
reasoning. In a recent issue of the fraternity magazine,
the national urged chapters to "make it clear that selfdetermination, not 'discrimination' is the issue." When,
however, a clause is interpreted to mean that neither
Negroes nor Orthodox Jews can he pledged, it is difficult to believe that the issue can he anything but diserimination.
The Administration must intervene.
